definition: Dendritic antigen-presenting cells residing in the mid-spinous layer of the epidermis, derived from CD34+ stem cells.
clinical: Historical context: Discovered by medical student Paul Langerhans using gold chloride. Function: Antigen presentation. Connected to unmyelinated nerve fibers (neuro-immune axis).
pathogenesis: Derived from CD34+ bone marrow stem cells. Migrate to skin.
microscopic: Located in the mid-spinous layer (suprabasal), maintaining a 'toehold' at the dermal-epidermal junction. Difficult to see on H&E (incognito). Dendritic morphology.
ancillary_studies: Stains: S100 positive, CD1a positive, Langerin (CD207) positive. Electron Microscopy: Birbeck granules (tennis/squash racket shape with trilaminar handle).
differential_diagnosis: Indeterminate cells (Langerin negative), Melanocytes (basal layer), Merkel cells.

related_figures.legend: Summary of Langerhans cell markers: Gold chloride (historical), S100, CD1a, and Langerin (CD207). (Time: 459s)
H&E stain showing Langerhans cells in the mid-spinous layer. (Time: 621s)
Electron microscopy showing Birbeck granules (squash racket shape). (Time: 762s)
Connection between unmyelinated nerve fiber and Langerhans cell. (Time: 777s)

definition: Populations of dendritic cells residing in the dermis, distinct from Langerhans cells.
clinical: Role in stabilizing fibrin monomers to polymers (Factor XIIIa+ cells) to stop bleeding.
pathogenesis: CD34+ cells in the dermis may differentiate into Factor XIIIa+ cells and vice versa.
microscopic: Factor XIIIa+ dendrocytes: Reticular dermis and around superficial plexus. CD34+ dendrocytes: Mid and deep reticular dermis.
ancillary_studies: Factor XIIIa positive (associated with Dermatofibroma). CD34 positive (associated with DFSP).

related_figures.legend: Dermal dendrocytes stained with enzymatic method. (Time: 837s)
Factor XIIIa stain showing dendritic cells around small vessels and interstitially. (Time: 889s)
CD34 stain showing dermal dendritic cells. (Time: 944s)

definition: A clonal neoplasm of Langerhans cells, formerly known as Histiocytosis X.
clinical: Presentations: 1. Acute disseminated (Letterer-Siwe): Seborrheic dermatitis-like scale on scalp, pink papules (groin/axilla), nail unit involvement, lung nodules. 2. Chronic multifocal (Hand-Schuller-Christian). 3. Eosinophilic Granuloma (focal bone/skin nodule).
pathogenesis: Clonal neoplasm (confirmed by X-inactivation). Mutations: BRAF V600E (associated with more extensive disease) or MAP2K1 mutations (mutually exclusive).
macroscopic: Yellow flaky scale (scalp), pink papules, erosions.
microscopic: Superficial form: Band-like infiltrate in papillary dermis, edema (major clue vs MF), psoriasiform hyperplasia, erosions. Nodular form: Sheets of cells in dermis. Cells: Large, abundant cytoplasm, reniform (kidney-bean) or coffee-bean nuclei with longitudinal grooves. Background: Eosinophils (variable, often abundant).
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD1a (+), S100 (+), Langerin/CD207 (+) (Distinguishes from Indeterminate Cell Histiocytosis). MAP kinase markers: BRAF V600E (+), Phospho-ERK (+).
differential_diagnosis: Scabies (clinical mimic, nodules can have dendritic cells), Spongiotic Dermatitis/Eczema (Langerhans cell microgranulomas are CD1a+, but cells are dendritic, not round/oval), Mycosis Fungoides (cells smaller, less cytoplasm, no papillary dermal edema).
staging: Varies from single system (skin/bone) to multisystem risk organ involvement.
prognosis_and_prediction: Depends on systemic involvement. BRAF mutations may correlate with extensive disease.

related_figures.legend: Seborrheic dermatitis-like presentation with yellow flaky scale on scalp. (Time: 1178s)
Band-like infiltrate in papillary dermis mimicking Mycosis Fungoides. (Time: 1289s)
Strong CD1a positivity in the dermal infiltrate. (Time: 1344s)
High power showing cells with reniform and grooved (coffee-bean) nuclei. (Time: 1528s)
Langerhans cell microgranuloma in eczema (Pitfall: CD1a+ but reactive). (Time: 1656s)

definition: A self-limiting variant of LCH presenting at birth (Hashimoto-Pritzker).
clinical: Papules/nodules present at or shortly after birth. Lesions ulcerate/break down and spontaneously regress. Some cases may persist as conventional LCH.
microscopic: Large, pale Langerhans cells (S100+, CD1a+) with areas of massive apoptosis ('desolate' areas).
differential_diagnosis: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (persistent forms), Lymphomatoid Papulosis.
prognosis_and_prediction: Excellent (self-healing), though surveillance recommended as some persist.

related_figures.legend: Band of pale cells surrounding a central area of massive apoptosis. (Time: 1825s)
S100 stain highlighting the histiocytes. (Time: 1845s)

definition: A proliferation of dendritic cells that phenotypically mimic Langerhans cells (CD1a+) but lack Birbeck granules and Langerin expression.
clinical: Solitary papule or multiple lesions. More common in adults than children (unlike LCH).
microscopic: Dermal infiltrate of histiocytes with morphology similar to LCH (abundant cytoplasm, some grooves) but often less epidermotropism/edema.
ancillary_studies: CD1a (+), S100 (+). CRITICAL: Langerin (CD207) NEGATIVE. Electron Microscopy: No Birbeck granules.
differential_diagnosis: Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (Langerin+, Birbeck granules+), Rosai-Dorfman Disease (S100+, CD1a-).

related_figures.legend: Diagram of the ETV3-NCOA2 gene fusion. (Time: 1902s)
CD1a stain showing strong positivity. (Time: 1987s)
Langerin (CD207) stain: Negative in tumor cells (positive internal control in normal epidermis). (Time: 1995s)

definition: A form of xanthoma associated with severe hypertriglyceridemia, presenting as crops of small yellow papules.
clinical: Crops of yellow papules, often on buttocks/extensors. Associated with high triglycerides.
pathogenesis: Leakage of lipid from vasculature exceeding macrophage phagocytic capacity.
microscopic: Foamy histiocytes. Extracellular lipid appears as 'feathery' material in the dermis (resembling gout crystals slightly but feathery).
prognosis_and_prediction: Resolves with lipid lowering; indicates risk of pancreatitis.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation of multiple papules. (Time: 2057s)
Feathery extracellular lipid material in the dermis. (Time: 2094s)

definition: Nodular lipid deposits in the skin associated with hyperlipidemia.
clinical: Firm nodules, often on extensor surfaces (knees, elbows).

related_figures.legend: Laminated fibrosis with foamy histiocytes. (Time: 2125s)

definition: Lipid deposits within tendons, commonly the Achilles or extensor tendons of hands.
microscopic: Foamy histiocytes expanding the tendon fascicles.
differential_diagnosis: Giant Cell Tumor of Tendon Sheath.

related_figures.legend: Tendon expanded by foamy histiocytes. (Time: 2135s)

definition: The most common form of xanthoma, occurring on the eyelids.
clinical: Yellow soft plaques on eyelids (medial canthus).
pathogenesis: May or may not be associated with hyperlipidemia.
microscopic: Clusters of foamy histiocytes in the superficial dermis. Often visually subtle on H&E compared to clinical appearance.

related_figures.legend: Yellow plaque on the eyelid. (Time: 2169s)
Clusters of foamy histiocytes in the dermis. (Time: 2177s)

definition: A rare non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis mainly affecting children and young adults, involving skin and mucosa.
clinical: Cutaneous papules/nodules (flexural/axilla/eyelids). Mucosal involvement. Pituitary involvement (Diabetes Insipidus ~40%).
pathogenesis: Unknown molecular cause. Associated with plasma cell dyscrasias/monoclonal gammopathy.
macroscopic: Red-brown to yellow papules coalescing into plaques.
microscopic: Sheets of foamy histiocytes, scalloped histiocytes, Touton giant cells. Resembles JXG but distinct distribution.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation involving the axilla. (Time: 2188s)
H&E showing foamy histiocytes and lymphocytes. (Time: 2241s)

definition: A granulomatous non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis strongly associated with paraproteinemia.
clinical: Indurated yellow-red plaques, typically periorbital ('raccoon eyes'). Orbital pseudotumor (proptosis).
pathogenesis: Strong association with paraproteinemia (IgG) and hyperlipidemia.
microscopic: Palisaded granulomas (mimicking Necrobiosis Lipoidica). Cholesterol clefts within granulomas ('Cholesterol Granulomas'). Bizarre giant cells with numerous (20-30) nuclei arranged in wreath or totem-pole shapes.
differential_diagnosis: Necrobiosis Lipoidica (typically legs, no cholesterol clefts, fewer giant cells), Granuloma Annulare.
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic, requires monitoring for hematologic malignancy (myeloma).

related_figures.legend: Periorbital 'raccoon eye' presentation. (Time: 2345s)
Palisaded granulomas similar to NLD. (Time: 2418s)
Cholesterol clefts forming 'Cholesterol Granulomas'. (Time: 2435s)
Bizarre giant cell with numerous nuclei. (Time: 2449s)

definition: A benign non-Langerhans cell histiocytosis occurring in children and adults (term 'Xanthogranuloma' preferred).
clinical: Solitary (most common) or multiple yellow-orange to red-brown papules/nodules. Common sites: Head/neck (scalp, nose). Rare disseminated forms affect liver, kidney, pericardium.
pathogenesis: Gene fusions: NTRK1 fusions (approx 50% solitary), ALK fusions.
microscopic: Dense sheet-like infiltrate of mononuclear histiocytes (pale/lipidized cytoplasm). Touton Giant Cells (ring of nuclei, homogeneous eosinophilic center, foamy periphery).
differential_diagnosis: Dermatofibroma (Factor XIIIa+ but spindle cells, no Touton giant cells), Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (S100+, CD1a+).
prognosis_and_prediction: Benign, often spontaneously regresses. Disseminated forms require MAPK pathway inhibition.

related_figures.legend: Large nodule on the nose of a child. (Time: 2503s)
Low power showing nodular infiltrate of histiocytes. (Time: 2591s)
High power showing characteristic Touton giant cell with ring of nuclei and foamy periphery. (Time: 2614s)
Autopsy specimen (kidney) from rare disseminated case. (Time: 2667s)
